situation: Facing a difficult choice about fulfilling one’s duty despite fear of unfavorable outcomes.
shloka: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन | मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि || (Chapter 2, Verse 47)
Translation: You have the right to perform your prescribed duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions. Never consider yourself to be the cause of the results of your activities, nor be attached to inaction.

Traditional Indian royal banners flutter, temple spires silhouette in the misty background, and the sky glows with soft pastel hues symbolizing wisdom and resolution.

situation: Struggling with motivation and attachment while performing one’s responsibilities.
shloka: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर | असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः || (Chapter 3, Verse 7)
Translation: Therefore, without attachment, always perform the work that has to be done; by performing work without attachment one attains the Supreme.
imageDescritpion: A majestic Indian palace courtyard where a noble warrior meditates peacefully, surrounded by intricate stone carvings and flowing water. The mood is serene and disciplined, capturing the essence of detachment and steady duty in the heart of an ancient Indian kingdom.

situation: Concerned about acting only for duty and not for personal gain or results.
shloka: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन | मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि || (Chapter 3, Verse 8)
Translation: Your right is to perform your duties only, but never to the fruits of those actions. You should never be motivated by the results nor should you give up doing your duty.
